My vision is to provide accessible first aid guidance in emergencies, especially for those without medical knowledge. This AI aims to:

  • Deliver instant, life-saving instructions
  • Simplify complex medical procedures
  • Bridge gaps until professional help arrives

Every remedy here is carefully curated to be easy-to-follow yet medically accurate for critical situations.

For minor cuts and scrapes:

  1. Wash your hands with soap and water.
  2. Rinse the wound under clean running water to remove debris and bacteria.
  3. Clean around the wound with mild soap and water.
  4. Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or bandage to stop bleeding.
  5. Apply an antibiotic ointment to prevent infection.
  6. Cover with a sterile bandage.
  7. Change the bandage daily and keep the wound clean.

Seek medical attention if:

  • The cut is deep or has jagged edges
  • The bleeding doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure
  • The wound is from a dirty or rusty object
  • There is significant redness, swelling, or pus
  • You haven't had a tetanus shot in the last 5 years

For minor burns (1st degree or small 2nd degree):

  1. Cool the burn immediately with cool (not cold) running water for 10-15 minutes.
  2. Do not use ice as it can damage the tissue.
  3. Remove jewelry or tight items from the burned area before swelling occurs.
  4. Apply a gentle moisturizer or aloe vera gel to soothe the skin.
  5. If needed, take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen.
  6. Cover with a sterile, non-stick bandage.

Do NOT:

  • Break blisters (increases risk of infection)
  • Apply butter, oil, or ointments (can trap heat)
  • Use cotton balls (fibers can stick to the burn)

Seek immediate medical attention for:

  • Burns larger than 3 inches (7.5 cm) in diameter
  • Third-degree burns (charred skin, white or brown areas)
  • Burns on the face, hands, feet, genitals, or major joints
  • Chemical or electrical burns

To treat a nosebleed:

  1. Sit down and lean slightly forward (not backward).
  2. Pinch the soft part of your nose shut for 10-15 minutes.
  3. Breathe through your mouth.
  4. Apply a cold compress to the bridge of your nose.
  5. Stay upright to reduce blood pressure in the nasal veins.
  6. After bleeding stops, avoid picking or blowing your nose for several hours.

Seek medical attention if:

  • Bleeding doesn't stop after 20-30 minutes of pressure
  • The nosebleed follows a head injury
  • You're taking blood thinners
  • You have frequent nosebleeds
  • There is a large amount of blood loss or you feel dizzy

To treat a sprain, follow the R.I.C.E. method:

  1. Rest: Avoid using the injured area for 24-48 hours.
  2. Ice: Apply ice for 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours for the first 48 hours.
  3. Compression: Use an elastic bandage to reduce swelling, but not too tight.
  4. Elevation: Keep the injured limb above heart level when possible.

Additional recommendations:

  • Take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen to reduce pain and inflammation.
  • After 48 hours, gentle heat can be applied to increase circulation and healing.
  • Begin gentle movement after the initial swelling subsides.

Seek medical attention if:

  • You cannot put weight on the injured joint
  • The joint looks deformed
  • There is severe swelling or bruising
  • Pain is intense and doesn't improve with rest
  • You heard a popping sound at the time of injury

For adults and children over 1 year:

  1. If the person can cough forcefully, encourage them to continue coughing.
  2. If they cannot cough, speak, or breathe, stand behind them.
  3. Wrap your arms around their waist.
  4. Make a fist with one hand and place it above the navel (thumb side in).
  5. Grab your fist with your other hand.
  6. Perform quick, upward thrusts into their abdomen until the object is expelled.

For infants under 1 year:

  1. Place the infant face down on your forearm, supporting their head.
  2. Give up to 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades.
  3. If unsuccessful, turn the infant face up and give up to 5 chest thrusts.
  4. Repeat until the object is dislodged.

Call emergency services (911) immediately if:

  • The person loses consciousness
  • You cannot remove the obstruction
  • The person is turning blue

To treat a bee sting:

  1. Remove the stinger by scraping it with a flat-edged object like a credit card (don't use tweezers).
  2. Wash the area with soap and water.
  3. Apply a cold pack wrapped in cloth for 10-20 minutes to reduce swelling and pain.
  4. Consider applying a paste of baking soda and water to neutralize the venom.
  5. Take an antihistamine or use hydrocortisone cream to reduce itching and swelling.
  6. Over-the-counter pain relievers can help with discomfort.

Seek emergency medical help immediately if the person develops:

  • Difficulty breathing
  • Swelling of the face, throat, or mouth
  • Rapid heartbeat
  • Dizziness or fainting
  • Hives or severe swelling beyond the sting site

These could be signs of a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) and require immediate medical attention.

To treat heat exhaustion:

  1. Move the person to a cool, shaded area.
  2. Remove excess clothing.
  3. Cool the person with cold compresses or a cool bath.
  4. Fan the person to help lower body temperature.
  5. Provide cold water or sports drinks (without caffeine or alcohol).
  6. Have the person lie down and elevate their legs.

Signs of heat exhaustion:

  • Heavy sweating
  • Cold, pale, clammy skin
  • Fast, weak pulse
  • Nausea or vomiting
  • Muscle cramps
  • Tiredness or weakness
  • Dizziness
  • Headache

Seek emergency medical help if:

  • Symptoms worsen or last longer than 1 hour
  • The person vomits repeatedly
  • Body temperature rises above 104Â°F (40Â°C)
  • The person becomes confused or unconscious

These could be signs of heat stroke, which is a life-threatening emergency.

For a minor head injury:

  1. Apply a cold pack to the injured area for 15-20 minutes to reduce swelling.
  2. Rest and avoid physical activities.
  3. Monitor for signs of a more serious injury.
  4. Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) for pain if needed, but avoid ibuprofen or aspirin as they may increase bleeding risk.

Seek immediate medical attention if the person:

  • Loses consciousness, even briefly
  • Has a severe headache or one that worsens
  • Experiences repeated vomiting or nausea
  • Has seizures
  • Shows confusion or unusual behavior
  • Has clear fluid draining from ears or nose
  • Has slurred speech
  • Has weakness or numbness in arms or legs
  • Has unequal pupil sizes
  • Cannot be awakened

For 24 hours after a head injury, someone should monitor the injured person and wake them every 2-3 hours if they're sleeping to check their condition.

To remove a splinter:

  1. Clean your hands and the affected area with soap and water.
  2. Sterilize tweezers and a needle with alcohol.
  3. If part of the splinter is sticking out, gently grasp it with tweezers at the surface of the skin and pull it out at the same angle it went in.
  4. If the splinter is embedded, gently scrape the skin with the needle until you expose an edge, then use tweezers to remove it.
  5. For deep splinters, soak the area in warm water with Epsom salt for 10-15 minutes to help draw it closer to the surface.
  6. After removal, clean the area with soap and water, apply antibiotic ointment, and cover with a bandage.

Seek medical attention if:

  • The splinter is deeply embedded and you cannot remove it
  • The splinter is under a nail
  • The area becomes increasingly red, swollen, or painful
  • You see signs of infection (pus, warm skin, red streaks)
  • The splinter is large or dirty
  • You haven't had a tetanus shot in the last 5 years

For poison ivy, oak, or sumac exposure:

  1. Immediately rinse the exposed skin with lukewarm water and soap.
  2. Wash all clothing, shoes, and tools that may have touched the plant.
  3. Apply cool compresses to the affected area for 15-30 minutes several times a day.
  4. Use calamine lotion or hydrocortisone cream to reduce itching.
  5. Take an oral antihistamine like Benadryl to help with itching and sleep.
  6. Avoid scratching, which can lead to infection.
  7. Take lukewarm oatmeal baths to soothe the skin.

The rash typically:

  • Appears within 12-72 hours after exposure
  • Lasts for 1-3 weeks
  • Does not spread through touching the rash or fluid from blisters

Seek medical attention if:

  • The rash covers a large part of your body
  • The rash is on your face or genitals
  • Blisters are oozing pus
  • You develop a fever over 100Â°F (37.8Â°C)
  • The rash doesn't improve after a week
  • You have difficulty breathing

To treat mild to moderate dehydration:

  1. Drink water or oral rehydration solutions like Pedialyte or sports drinks.
  2. Take small, frequent sips rather than large amounts at once.
  3. Avoid caffeine and alcohol, which can worsen dehydration.
  4. For infants and children, use oral rehydration solutions specifically formulated for them.
  5. Rest in a cool place.
  6. Eat fruits and vegetables with high water content (watermelon, cucumber, oranges).

Signs of dehydration:

  • Thirst
  • Dry or sticky mouth
  • Dark yellow urine
  • Headache
  • Muscle cramps
  • Fatigue
  • Dizziness
  • Decreased urination

Seek medical attention for severe dehydration if:

  • There is extreme thirst
  • Irritability or confusion
  • Very dry mouth, skin, and mucous membranes
  • Little or no urination for 8 hours
  • Sunken eyes
  • Shriveled skin
  • Low blood pressure
  • Rapid heartbeat
  • Rapid breathing
  • Fever
  • Delirium or unconsciousness

To treat frostbite:

  1. Move to a warm area as soon as possible.
  2. Remove wet or tight clothing and jewelry.
  3. Warm the affected area by immersing it in warm (not hot) water (104-108Â°F or 40-42Â°C) for 15-30 minutes.
  4. For face or ears, use warm compresses.
  5. Do not rub or massage the affected area as this can cause more damage.
  6. Do not use direct heat sources like heating pads, radiators, or fires.
  7. Take over-the-counter pain medications if needed.
  8. After warming, wrap the area in clean, soft, dry bandages, separating affected toes or fingers.

Signs of frostbite:

  • Cold, numb skin
  • Redness, followed by gray/blue discoloration
  • Hard or waxy-looking skin
  • Blistering in severe cases

Seek immediate medical attention if:

  • The area is completely numb
  • The skin appears white, gray, or blistered
  • The symptoms don't improve with basic treatment
  • There are signs of infection
  • The frostbite affects large areas or is on the face, hands, or feet

During an asthma attack:

  1. Help the person sit upright comfortably and stay calm.
  2. Assist them in using their rescue inhaler (usually albuterol) if available.
  3. Instruct them to take one puff at a time, with 4-5 deep breaths between puffs.
  4. Have them repeat this process for up to 3 puffs.
  5. Remove any obvious triggers (pets, smoke, dust).
  6. Encourage slow, steady breathing.
  7. If they have a peak flow meter, help them use it to assess severity.

Call emergency services (911) immediately if:

  • The person's symptoms don't improve after using the inhaler
  • The person's lips or fingernails turn blue or gray
  • The person has trouble walking or talking
  • The person's nostrils flare with breathing
  • The skin around their ribs and neck pulls in with each breath
  • The person loses consciousness

While waiting for help, continue to monitor the person and help them use their rescue inhaler every 20 minutes if needed.

For mild to moderate allergic reactions:

  1. Take an oral antihistamine like Benadryl (diphenhydramine) or Claritin (loratadine).
  2. Apply hydrocortisone cream to relieve itching for skin reactions.
  3. Remove the allergy trigger if possible.
  4. Apply cold compresses to reduce swelling.
  5. For food allergies, rinse your mouth and drink water.
  6. Monitor symptoms closely for any worsening.

Signs of a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis):

  • Difficulty breathing or swallowing
  • Swelling of the lips, tongue, throat, or face
  • Tightness in the chest or throat
  • Wheezing or high-pitched breathing sounds
  • Dizziness, fainting, or loss of consciousness
  • Rapid heartbeat
  • Vomiting, diarrhea, or cramping
  • Widespread hives or severe itching

For anaphylaxis:

  1. Call 911 immediately
  2. If the person has an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen), help them use it
  3. Have them lie flat with legs elevated (unless breathing is difficult)
  4. If unconscious and not breathing, begin CPR

During a seizure:

  1. Stay calm and note the time the seizure begins.
  2. Move furniture or other objects away to prevent injury.
  3. Gently guide the person to the floor or a flat surface if possible.
  4. Place something soft under their head.
  5. Turn them onto their side to prevent choking if fluid or vomit appears.
  6. Stay with them until the seizure ends.
  7. After the seizure, help them into a recovery position (on their side).
  8. Speak calmly and reassuringly as they regain awareness.

Do NOT:

  • Restrain the person
  • Put anything in their mouth
  • Try to give them food or drink until fully alert
  • Move them unless they're in danger

Call 911 if:

  • The seizure lasts longer than 5 minutes
  • The person doesn't wake up after the seizure ends
  • The person has a second seizure
  • The person is injured during the seizure
  • The person has difficulty breathing
  • The person has a high fever
  • The person is pregnant or has diabetes
  • This is their first seizure

Emergency treatment for heatstroke:

  1. Call 911 immediately.
  2. Move the person to a cool, shaded area.
  3. Remove excess clothing.
  4. Cool the person rapidly with cold water (immersion or spray).
  5. Apply ice packs to armpits, neck, and groin.
  6. Monitor body temperature until it drops to 101Â°F (38.3Â°C).
  7. Do NOT give fluids if unconscious.

Signs of heatstroke:

  • Body temperature â‰¥104Â°F (40Â°C)
  • Altered mental state (confusion, slurred speech)
  • Hot, dry skin OR excessive sweating
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Rapid heartbeat
  • Loss of consciousness

When someone faints:

  1. Lay the person flat on their back and elevate legs 12 inches.
  2. Loosen tight clothing.
  3. Check for breathing/pulse.
  4. If vomiting occurs, roll them onto their side.
  5. Do NOT give food/water until fully alert.
  6. After waking, let them rest for 15-20 minutes.

Call 911 if:

  • Unconscious for >1 minute
  • Difficulty breathing
  • Chest pain or irregular heartbeat
  • Head injury during fall
  • Seizures or confusion after waking

For eye emergencies:

  1. Chemical exposure: Flush with lukewarm water for 15-20 minutes.
  2. Foreign object: Blink repeatedly or rinse with saline.
  3. Physical trauma: Apply a cold compress (no pressure).
  4. Cover both eyes to reduce movement.

Do NOT:

  • Rub the eye
  • Remove embedded objects
  • Use tweezers

Seek immediate care for:

  • Vision changes
  • Severe pain
  • Blood in the eye
  • Pupil abnormalities

To save a permanent tooth:

  1. Handle by the crown (top), not the root.
  2. Rinse gently with milk or saline (no scrubbing).
  3. Reinsert into socket if possible (bite down on gauze).
  4. If not, store in milk or saliva (NOT water).
  5. See a dentist within 30 minutes for best results.

For baby teeth: Do not reinsertâ€”see a dentist.

For snake bites:

  1. Call 911 immediately.
  2. Keep the person calm and still.
  3. Remove jewelry/tight clothing near the bite.
  4. Position the bite below heart level.
  5. Clean with soap/water (no flushing).
  6. Cover with a clean, dry bandage.

Do NOT:

  • Cut the wound
  • Suck out venom
  • Apply ice/tourniquet
  • Give alcohol/caffeine

Note the snake's appearance (color, shape) for antivenom.
